work.summary: Promote conscious consumerism by advocating for American manufactured goods
highlights: E-commerce website using various frameworks from its inception in 2013 to 2015
Database Architecture: Designed MySQL schema to support over three million products, with real time natural languages search capabilities using sphinx
Data Collection: Automatically collect data from amazon.com. Products from 30,000 category nodes using 5 search terms in one week totalling in millions of data points
Advised CEO in making business and technology related decisions
Mentored and trained new employees and interns

Data collection infrastructure and “real time data replay” feature to facilitate analysis of user activity
Literature reviews, user observations, data analysis, and research papers / posters

publications.name: openHTML: Designing a transitional web editor for novices
publications.publisher: CHI '13 Extended Abstracts on Human Factors in Computing Systems
publications.summary: We describe the initial design rationale and early findings from studies of a web editor for beginners called openHTML. We explain our strategy of transitional design that views web editors as a part of a complex socio-technical system that spans multiple tools, practices, and actors. Our goal is to create a toolkit that can engage beginners in meaningful activities now and prepare them for more sophisticated activities in the future.

publications.name: Towards a taxonomy of errors in HTML and CSS
publications.publisher: ICER '13 Proceedings of the ninth annual international ACM conference on International computing education research
publications.summary: As part of a larger research agenda to explore web development as a context for learning computational literacy skills, we investigate errors people make while writing code in HTML and CSS. We report on a lab-based study in which 20 participants were video recorded as they completed coding tasks. We have applied the skills-rules-knowledge framework to segment this data by the cognitive causes of errors they made, and present a taxonomy of these errors. Our findings demonstrate how the skills-rules-framework can be used to analyze coding errors, provide insight about the origins of these errors, and suggest ways that the design of web development tools can be improved to support learning and practice with HTML and CSS.
